smell_analysis.justification: All diagrams in the file contain at least one modeled element such as a package, use case, class, table, activity node, or state; no page labelled as a diagram is empty.

In the use case diagrams Pakiautomaatide funktsionaalne allsüsteem (page 2) and Primary Use Cases (page 8), every use case oval is connected by at least one association line to an actor, and other pages that list functions inside packages do not show visual ovals and are excluded from this rule.

Across the use case diagrams, there are no pairs of use cases whose names describe the same activity and that are associated with the same actor; each oval name is unique, such as Tuvasta kasutaja, Registreeri pakiautomaat, Vaata aktiivseid pakiautomaate, Use Case1 and Use Case2.

In the package diagram on page 1, the elements listed inside each package (registers and the subsystem) all have distinct primary names; similar phrases like Kasutusjuhu 'registreeri pakiautomaat' and Registreeri pakiautomaat differ in their primary names, so there are no duplicate model elements within the same package.

In the conceptual and transformed database/class diagrams (pages 18-23 and 26-30), columns that represent identifiers or codes (for example Pakiautomaadi_kood, Seisundi_liigi_kood, isik_id) are consistently linked via explicit foreign key relationships, and there is no clear case where the same data value is stored redundantly in multiple tables without an FK connector.

Within each use case diagram, the naming form is internally consistent: on page 2 all use cases begin with a verb in Estonian (for example Tuvasta kasutaja, Registreeri pakiautomaat, Vaata kõiki pakiautomaate), while on page 8 both use cases share the neutral template style Use Case1 and Use Case2, so no single diagram mixes verb-first and noun-first naming.

The state diagram Pakiautomaatide seisundidiagramm on page 24 shows all states (Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud, Unustatud) with at least one incoming transition from the initial state or from another state; there is no state drawn without any incoming arrow, so no unreachable state is evident.

In all activity diagrams (pages 3-5 and 11-17), every action box participates in a control flow starting from an initial node and leading through decisions and actions to an end node; there are no action nodes visually disconnected from the main flow, so no unreachable actions can be identified.

All associations between classes or tables in the class and database diagrams show multiplicities such as 1 and 0..* near the line ends (for example between Isik and Kasutajakonto, or between Pakiautomaat and Pakiautomaadi_Tootja), or are drawn as standard crow's-foot or foreign-key connectors in the transformed diagrams; no relationship line is completely missing multiplicity information at both ends.

At least two diagrams exceed the threshold of 10 central elements: the use case diagram Pakiautomaatide funktsionaalne allsüsteem on page 2 contains 11 distinct use cases, and the conceptual class diagram Kontseptuaalne eskiismudel on page 18 contains more than 10 classes (including Isik, Kasutajakonto, Töötaja, Pakiautomaat and several classifier types).

The class diagram Isikute register on page 20 shows the Isik class connected by separate relationship lines to at least six other elements (Isiku_seisundi_liik, Riik, Kasutajakonto, Klient, Töötaja and the self-relationship Isiku roll), and transformed diagrams such as Isikute register (transformed) on page 27 and Pakiautomaatide register (transformed) on page 30 similarly depict central tables with six or more distinct association or foreign-key lines, satisfying the 6+ relationship threshold for a single element in one diagram.

Although some related elements are placed near the edges of diagrams, no relationship line is clearly much longer than the others in a way that would make its length more than twice the average distance between connected elements; therefore no unambiguous spacing outlier can be identified.

Several use case and activity names do not start with an active verb: in the Primary Use Cases diagram on page 8 the use case ovals are named Use Case1 and Use Case2 (starting with the noun 'Use'), and in activity diagrams there are actions such as 'Pakiautomaatide haldur avaldab soov uue pakiautomaadi registreerida' (page 5) and 'Subjekt logib sisse süsteemi' (page 11) whose names begin with an actor noun instead of a verb.

Across the diagrams, names of classes, tables, attributes and use cases are longer than three characters (for example Isik, E_mail, Pakiautomaat, Seisundi_liigi_kood); no element name of length three or fewer characters, such as 'id' or 'nr', appears as a standalone identifier.

All class names for domain objects in the class and database diagrams (such as Isik, Töötaja, Pakiautomaat, Kasutajakonto, Klient) start with an uppercase letter and are written in singular form; plural-like constructs occur only in register names like Isikute register or Pakiautomaatide register, which are explicitly excluded from this rule.

Many attributes and columns begin with an uppercase letter, for example Töö_e_mail in Töötaja on page 18, E_mail, Eesnimi and Perenimi in Isik on page 20, and Seisundi_liigi_nimetus and On_Aktiivne in several transformed classifier tables on pages 27-28, so the requirement that attribute or column names start with a lowercase letter is violated.

Database tables that represent individual domain entities such as Isik, Klient, Pakiautomaat, Töötaja and Kasutajakonto are all named in singular form; plural-like genitive phrases appear only as parts of classifier or register names such as Pakiautomaatide_kategooria or Kliendi_seisundi_liik, which denote sets or classification types rather than singular entities.

Class, table and attribute names do not use technical prefixes indicating their type such as 'tbl_', 'uc_' or 'str_'; the only prefixes present are PK_, FK_, pfK_ and IXFK_ in key and index names, which are explicitly allowed by the rule and are not used as class or attribute identifiers.
